comments.body: this looks like it was accidental?
it's confusing when looking at this enum that there's no state for "accepted". The enum description should discuss why this is.
Typo: plural "recognizers" should be singular "recognizer"

Another option here that might be cleaner would be to have a single interface implemented by both GestureArena and GestureArenaTeam, and have all gestures always be assigned an "owner", which is used here.

That would avoid the GestureRecognizer needing to know about GestureArenaTeam. It seems weird for it to know about teams. It would also remove another use of a global static, and would therefore allow you to run multiple arenas at the same time (which might be useful when you have multiple pipelines or something).
Can an @required argument be optional?
Oops, I didn't mean to leave it required.
You could explain the debugReport parameter here
done

This needs mode information. By just reading this I have no idea what this does.

Maybe also have a "See also" section linking to the example you gave for [DragGestureRecognizer. dragStartBehavior].
Could we call these constants `preAcceptTolerance` etc? I think "slop" was a crude synonym for "tolerance".
Might be my English fail again. Though I think slop is just the 'spill' or the 'departure'. 'preAcceptSpillTolerance' is still what's intended.
or beyond [postAcceptSlopTolerance] from where the pointer was when the gesture was accepted.
done
Rejected or cancelled? It seems like once we've accepted a gesture...
Does 'cancel' have a specific technical meaning? I'm referring to resolve(GestureDisposition.rejected) here which causes all subsequent callbacks to no longer be called.
yes, cancel means the gesture aborted, e.g. because of a pointer cancel event.
It looks like the abarth comment about factoring out slop (drag tolerance) handling should survive

Umm I did it by accident, but on second thought, I don't think I agree with the premise of the TODO anymore. This class almost doesn't do anything else besides dealing with the slop. I don't think there is another place to refactor this into.
feel free to remove the comment. we're eventually going to want to move the slop handling to a render object though, at least for some gestures.
I don't understand. If `isPostAcceptSlopPastTolerance` is true, then we know we've already been accepted, so what does it mean to reject it?

I don't have a strong opinion about this. I'm mostly leaning towards not introducing more API breaks in this PR since it was the existing behaviour (whether the gesture was accepted or not). Rejecting an accepted gesture makes future events not go through, such as the up event.
I don't understand how your comment corresponds to my question.

> If `isPostAcceptSlopPastTolerance` is true, then we know we've already been accepted

Yes

> so what does it mean to reject it?

In the existing implementation, 
```dart
if (event is PointerMoveEvent && _getDistance(event) > kTouchSlop) {
  resolve(GestureDisposition.rejected);
```
causes the recognizer to stop emitting post-accept events such as the up event. I leaned towards not altering that behavior and left it in this PR though we can make that change if we feel that we have a strong reason to.
this comment doesn't make much sense to me
i think we should assert that we're not accepted here. it doesn't make sense to reject when you're accepted.
It's the existing behavior since there are no knowledge of acceptance in this class yet. We're moving a step closer in this PR but I haven't changed this behavior.
i am not convinced about adding this. I don't really understand what it gives us.
Wonder why the reject is in OneSequenceGestureRecognizer and not here.
My thinking here was that recognizers that track multiple pointers may not want to reject if there's a non-allowed pointer in the middle, they would just ignore it.
This isn't ideal. If you have better ideas on how to improve it, I'm all ears :)

Ah, this is unfortunate. Though this event isn't entirely correct either right? Since you're sending something from the past and the past event also has a timeStamp. 

I haven't validated it but I suspect each onLongPressDown is preceded by a onTapDown or something. From the TextSelectionGestureDetector's perspective, it may be enough?

Unfortunately, this is how the tap recognizer works. It doesn't send the tap down event until either a tap up occurs, or the deadline is exceeded. And in that case, the tap down is always from the past (even before my change). All my change does is it adds the `kind` field to the event.
Is there any way to know what the local space is, or what it belongs to?

From just looking at a CombinedOffset instance, you will not know what the local coordinate pace is. However, it is clear from the context in which the CombinedOffset is used. E.g. when used within a GestureDetector it is the local coordinate space of that GestureDetector.
I am surprised that the return type can be null here.
It can be null because the catch block doesn't throw and then the result remains null
Why the `?` when the next line is a non-null check?
Oh, do getter and setter need to have the exact same type?

>do getter and setter need to have the exact same type?

Almost. The rule is that setter can accept the return of getter. See https://github.com/dart-lang/language/issues/331
making this a class with `==` seems dangerous, because one of the values is generated from the other using floating point math that may or may not give you precisely the same results each time.
Good point.  I removed the == / hashCode on this class.
This seems odd. Shouldn't it be nulled out if it's not tracking anything anymore?

This is needed so the recognizer knows what pointer it was tracking when the arena resolves -- which can often be after we've stopped tracking the pointer.  For example, if the arena was being held (imagine a double-tap recognizer is also in the arena, and we need to wait until that rejects the gesture to know that we've won).

I added extra comments to try to explain this.
